story: Leaders prepare for summit on nuclear weaponsThe meeting with Moon Jae-in is only the third time that leaders of the two countries have met in the 65 years since the Korean War – and the first time one of the Kim leaders has crossed over to the South.The two leader shook hands on the border line before Mr Kim crossed into the South. Mr Moon later crossed into the North as well, and the two posed for ceremonial photos facing each side. The event was also attended by school children, an honour guard and a military band. It was broadcast live across South Korea.North Korea's nuclear test site has collapsed, say geologistsThe ceremony took place outside the Peace House, a conference building on the south side of the border, where the two leaders planned to discuss the issue of nuclear weapons on Friday.North Korea's nuclear arsenal has developed rapidly in the last year, leading to tense exchanges between Mr Kim and US President Donald Trump. But the North and South have also made several unexpected steps toward peace, including marching under the same flag in the 2018 Pyeongchang Olympics.North Koreans breakout to Seoul North Koreans breakout to Seoul A hat belonging to Jeong Min-woo is seen in Seoul, South Korea, August 9, 2017. Min-woo is from Hyesan, on the border with China. He was a commissioned officer in the Korean People's Army, and left in his uniform. South Korean intelligence confiscated it, but he persuaded his North Korean military contacts to send him a new one.Jeong Min-woo, 29, poses for a photograph in Seoul, South Korea. Kang, 28, who wanted to be identified only by her surname, poses for a photograph in Seoul, South Korea. A dog fur coat belonging to Kang, who wanted to be identified only by her surname, is seen in Seoul, South Korea. Lee Oui-ryuk, 29, poses for a photograph in Seoul, South Korea, September 12, 2017. Oui-ryuk is from Onsong, near the border with China. He defected in 2010, and brought his ID card with him. Photographs and North Korean identification card of Lee Oui-ryuk are seen in Seoul, South Korea. Song Byeok, 48, poses for a photograph in Seoul, South Korea, September 27, 2017. Byeok was a propaganda artist. His father drowned trying to cross the Tumen river, in 2000. When the artist finally left North Korea in 2001, he brought photos of his family with him.A family photograph of Song Byeok is seen in Seoul, South Korea. Lee Min-bok, 60, poses for a photograph in Seoul, South Korea, September 14, 2017. Min-bok was a researcher at North Korea's Academy of Agricultural Science. He first tried to defect, unsuccessfully, in 1990. He eventually left North Korea in June 1991 and came to South Korea in 1995. His family sent him these diaries.Diaries written by Lee Min-bok are seen in Pocheon, South Korea. Ji Sung-ho, 35, poses for a photograph in Seoul, South Korea, August 13, 2017. Sung-ho is from Hoeryong, near the border with China. He left North Korea in 2006 with a pair of wooden crutches.Baek Hwa-sung, 33, poses for a photograph in Seoul, South Korea, September 30, 2017. Hwa-sung left Sinuiju, on the border with China, in 2003 and resettled in South Korea in 2008. He kept a diary as he defected. Diaries written by Baek Hwa-sung are seen in Seoul, South Korea. Kim Ryen Hui, 48, is reflected on a window as she poses for a photograph in Seoul, South Korea, November 14, 2017. Ryon Hui is from Pyongyang. A photo of Kim Ryen Hui's daughter is seen in Seoul, South Korea. The Olympics plan was hatched during an earlier meeting between North and South Korean diplomats, which went smoothly but skirted around the issue of nuclear weapons. This time around, North Korea's state news agency said Mr Kim would open-heartedly discuss all the issues arising in improving inter-Korean relations and achieving peace, prosperity and reunification of the Korean peninsula with Mr Moon.Mr Kim has also made plans to meet with Mr Trump, in what would be the first in-person meeting between a US and North Korean president in history. The North Korean leader has already met with Mike Pompeo, the director of the CIA, in preparation for the summit.The White House issued a statement on the inter-Korean summit on Thursday, saying the US was hopeful about the talks, and looked forward to the meeting between Mr Kim and Mr Trump. North Korea 'suspends' missile and nuclear testsBoth the US and South Korea would like to see the denuclearisation of the North, which is close to building a nuclear missile capable that can reach the US. Mr Kim has said he is open to discussing the denuclearisation of the Korean Peninsula with both leaders, but experts say he will likely require tough concessions from the Americans.  Among other things, Mr Kim has taken issue with the US soldiers stationed in South Korea, the joint military exercises the two countries perform, and the lack of a formal peace treaty to end the Korea War. He also wants the US to remove its nuclear umbrella over the Penninsula and the Northeast Asian region.The Korea peace talks wouldn't be happening without TrumpThe US's relationship with Iran remains as strained as everSouth Korea and the US have slightly different ideas about how to denuclearise the North, with Mr Moon favouring a step-by-step process and Mr Trump calling for the immediate destruction of the country's nuclear weapons.Mr Moon is likely setting the stage to serve as a mediator between the US and the North in this week's meeting, having acknowledged that any long-term solution on the Peninsula will require American input.“Peace on the Korean Peninsula cannot be achieved by agreements between South and North Korea alone,” he said last month. “It has to have American endorsement.”or register with your social accountAlready have an account? title: brexit customs union debate live news theresa may EU
story: MPs yesterday approved the non-binding motion, which called on the Government to include as an objective in Brexit negotiations the option of establishing an effective customs union between the UK and EU, without a vote.Signatories to the non-binding motion tabled by parliamentary committee chairs include four senior Tories: Bob Neill, Sarah Wollaston, Nicky Morgan and Dominic Grieve.Downing Street has played down its significance, saying it was a routine backbench business debate.Many prominent anti-EU campaigners did not show up to a parliamentary debate on urging the government to press for the negotiation of an effective customs union with the bloc after Brexit, after May ruled out any change in her stance.Their absence meant an expected showdown was little more than a painful reminder for May that she is far from winning the argument on Brexit even in her Conservative Party, and could be defeated in parliament later this year.The House of Commons approved the motion on a customs union verbally without a vote in a procedure that does not require the government to take any action.The, or a, customs union is one of the main flashpoints in the debate over Britain's impending exit from the EU and Brexit campaigners are sensitive to any suggestion that Britain might stay in such an association with the bloc.PARLIAMENTLIVE.TVCustoms union debate: MPs debate Theresa May's Brexit plansAnd the DUP, which is propping up the Tories in the Commons, has threatened to bring down the PM if she sacrificed the Government's position on the customs union.Leader Nigel Dodds said his party would vote against the Government if any Brexit red lines were crossed.Labour MP Yvette Cooper opened the Commons debate by saying motion was the first of the debates chosen by the Liason Committtee, adding it is on one of the most important issues that Parliament will have to take a decision on in the next six months.She admitted committee was ided over whether the UK should leave customs union &ndash supporting Mrs May&rsquosBrexit plans &ndash and or remain in the EU agreement.Read how yesterday's debate unfolded below                EU customs deal like Turkey's would mean &lsquosemi-colonial' status for UK                BBC Breakfast: Starmer GRILLED by BBC host over Labour's Brexit planTHURSDAY APRIL 264.50pm: MPs pass motion in favour of customs union4.07pm: Stella Creasy urges government to &lsquoeat the frog&rsquoShe said: &ldquoMy mother reaches a milestone birthday today. She has taught my many things including the &lsquoeat the frog&rsquo rule, which is that if you have something difficult to do in life, there is no sense prevaricating.&ldquoSo I am here today to ask the ministers to eat the frog when it comes to admitting there is no better alternative for this country than remaining in the customs union.3.48pm: Labour MP says vote was not about customs unionDulwich MP Helen Hayes accuses the referendum campaign of ignoring the EU customs union.She said: &ldquoIt was not articulated as an essential defining feature of Brexit.&ldquoCustoms union was a phrase that relatively few people knew until after the referendum.3.27pm: Owen Smith says hard border would be 'unconcionable'Mr Smith has moved onto Norther Ireland and the risk of a return to violence.&nbspHe said: &ldquoWe cannot countenance any return to any hard border in Northern Ireland. It would be utterly unconscionable for this place to allow that to happen.&ldquoThis place has to listen. It wasn&rsquot discussed prior to the referendum. It wasn&rsquot clear we were going to jeopardise peace in Northern Ireland. It is no clear that we run the risk if there is to be any sort of a harder border.&ldquoThat alone should cause us to pause, to say we must stay in the customs market and single market.PARLIAMENTLIVE.TVCustoms union debate: Anna Soubry says leaving the customs union will cost people their jobs3.24pm: Labour MP Owen Smith lashes out at BrexiteersHere&rsquos failed Labour leader candidate Owen Smith.He said he agrees with Labour MP and Brexiteer Kate Hoey&rsquos comments on the &ldquodishonesty in the Brexit debate.Mr Smith said: &ldquoIt&rsquos the only thing I agree with her on. The dishonesty in my view has been the hallmark of the Brexiteers prior to, during and after the debate.He accused Brexiteers of telling the country &ldquofibs.Joey Millar is now taking over running the liveblog from Nicole Stinson.&nbsp2.50pm:&nbspLabour MP Ruth George urges MPs to be good listeners says there is uncertainty over BrexitCiting local business concerns in her constituency of High Peak, she added: &ldquoBecause leaving the customs union will slow their supply chains up&hellip it will slow down their manufacturing and it will increase their costs.2.30pm:&nbspPlaid Cymru will remain steadfast in its push to keep the UK in the EU customs unionWelsh MP Hywel Williams reaffirmed his party Plaid Cymru&rsquos position has and will always be to stay in the customs union.2.25pm: Tory MP declares the Government must respect the referendum resultMatt Warnman, the Tory MP for Boston and Skegness, admitted that he voted to Remain but then also voted to trigger Brexit with Article 50.He added: &ldquoWe have to respect the result.2.10pm: Anna Soubry says that tariffs that will be imposed once the UK leaves the custom union willShe added that tariff would cause delays in trying to get good into the EU, adding: Time cost money.2.00pm: Former Tory Cabinet minister Nicky Morgan says disrupting the peace in Northern Ireland would be unforgivableConservative former cabinet minister Nicky Morgan warned that the Tories would not be forgiven for a generation if the party ignores the evidence for peace in Northern Ireland.Ms Morgan said: This country has been asked to experiment at other people's pleasure with a free trade policy where we do not know what the costs will be for constituents and businesses in this country.I say to my party: if we undermine and ignore the evidence for peace in Northern Ireland, and we undermine the business and financial security of the people in this country, we will not be forgiven for a generation.PARLIAMENTLIVE.TVCustoms union debate: Kate Hoey warned that there are still people trying to sabotage Brexit1.30pm Kate Hoey believes when the House of Commons votes on the customs union the result will be differentThe Labour MP added that she thought there were a lot of people in the Commons debate today who were tryin to use the issue of the customs union &ldquoto start the progress again to try and stay in the EU.1.20pm Labour MP Chuka Umunna says the UK will be poorer if it leaves the single market and the customs unionMr&nbspUmunna then challenges Mr Clarke to give and example where a govenment has been successful.Mr Clarke replied that is why the UK need a customs union not the current EU customs union where Britain cannot have trade agreements with third countries.Mr Umunna said: He will know this Government has been advised by its own officials that to leave the single market and customs union will make this country poorer.Can, in all his time in this House, he think of a government that has knowingly taken a decision of this gravity which will make the country poorer? Can he think of any example of any government he has seen where they have done that?Mr Clarke joked in reply: Not deliberately - accidentally several times.1.15pm Kenneth Clarke says all his colleagues in the Government and the House of Lords are in favour of staying in the customs unionMr Clarke added that while the UK may be leaving the customs union there needed to be a customs union or a replica of it.He continued that the UK needed to be able to need negotiate trade agreements with other countries which Britian cannot do in the customs union.1.00pm: Yvette Cooper says the motion calls for an effective customs unionDetailing her vision for a customs union agreement, the Labour MP said it would be for frictionless trade without tariffs.12.45pm: Business think tank hits back at claims made by Yvette Cooper in the House of CommonsIn an email to the Express Callum Crozier, policy director at leading northern business think tank, Policy North said: If the UK remains in the Customs Union, we will be unable to negotiate independent trade deals with other countries. People will then rightly ask in what way we have left the EU. This debate is simply an attempt to frustrate Brexit and undermine the referendum result.&ldquoIf we do not leave the Customs Union, there is no point in leaving the EU. Being &lsquoout&rsquo of the EU but having to abide by its tariffs and being unable to strike new trade deals with the rest of the world defies logic.&ldquoThe North of England economy is worth over &pound300bn and makes up 19 per cent of total UK output, but it has the potential to be so much more after Brexit, as long as we leave the Customs Union.&ldquoWith 90 per cent of global growth over the next 10-15 years set to be from non-EU countries, it makes no sense to lock ourselves out of these lucrative markets.&ldquoPolicy North has proposed establishing free ports in the North post Brexit. There are currently no functional Free Trade Zones in the UK because membership of the Single Market and Customs Union effectively prevents us from creating them. That&rsquos why leaving the Customs Union is essential.PARLIAMENTLIVE.TVCustom union debate: Kenneth Clarke says people are in favour of staying in the EU customs union12.40pm: Irish border solutions have been questioned by Yvette Cooper12.30pm:&nbspYvette Cooper says a customs union is the interest of the manufacturing industry and Northern IrelandThe Labour MP suggested the UK should stay in the custom union because it would benefit the manufacturing industry and solve the problems over the Irish border, adding in the conitnued interest of peace.12.26pm:&nbspLabour MP Yvette Cooper&nbsphas opened the debateYvette Cooper says today's moton is&nbspthe first of the debates chosen by the Liason Committtee, adding:it is on one of the most important issues that Parliament will have to take a decision on in the next six months.The motion has been put forward by 12 committee chairs.12:10pm: The House of Commons is running behind schedule but the customs union debate is expected to start soonSpeaking before the debate Nigel Dodds, the deputy leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, said his party would vote against the Government if any of its red lines on Brexit were crossed.Mr Dodds told the Conservativehome website: &ldquoIf, as a result of the Brexit negotiations for instance, there was to be any suggestion that Northern Ireland would be treated differently in a way, for instance that we were part of a customs union and a single market and the rest of the UK wasn&rsquot ... for us that would be a red line, which we would vote against the Government.Customs union debate: A vote is not expected at the end of today&rsquos non-binding debate&ldquoYou might as well have a Corbyn government pursuing openly its anti-Unionist policies as have a Conservative Government doing it by a different means.Meanwhile Labour&rsquos shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer accused the Prime Minister of delaying the showdown over the Taxation (Cross-border Trade) Bill because she fears a humiliating defeat.House of Commons library analysis commissioned by Labour indicated the decision to rule out a new customs union with the European Union could cost the UK economy &pound24 billion by 2033.Sir Keir said: Over the past few weeks it has become abundantly clear that Theresa May is unwilling and unable to put the country's interests first during the Brexit negotiations.She has wasted 12 weeks of the Brexit negotiations delaying a Commons vote on the UK negotiating a customs union with the EU for fear of a defeat.In light of the Government's own impact assessments and the lack of progress on any new trade deals, any economic case for ruling out a customs union has collapsed.The Prime Minister is now solely focused on internal party management and masking the isions within her government.But Brexit minister Suella Braverman said Labour's support for a customs union would leave the UK shackled to Brussels, taking rules set by the EU and unable to strike trade deals.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has backed a customs union but only if the UK had a say in future EU trade deals.Mrs Braverman said: The supposed safeguards that Corbyn talks about are impossible to achieve and will get laughed out of town.She said Labour was more interested in frustrating the process and playing politics than they are in delivering a successful Brexit.Labour Home Affairs Committee chairwoman Yvette Cooper and Treasury select committee chairwoman Ms Morgan said in a joint statement: We both believe the case for a customs union is overwhelming &ndash for the sake of British manufacturing, international trade, smooth borders and Northern Ireland peace.Additional reporting and initial liveblog by Nicole Stinson

title: Meghan Markle Prince Harry ex girlfriend Cressida Bonas bumps into
story: The future royal is believed to have met Prince Harry for the first time at Soho House in London just three days before her trip to Wimbledon.She then found herself in the awkward position of sitting inches away from Prince Harry&rsquos former fling on Centre Court.It is not clear whether Meghan and Cressida spoke at Wimbledon, but they were both photographed at the exclusive Ralph Lauren event.The Duchess of Cambridge&rsquos younger sister Pippa Middleton was also spotted sitting within touching distance from the future royal.REXMeghan Markle sat inches away from Prince Harry's ex-girlfriend Cressida Bonas at Wimbledon 2016                Why will the Queen attend Harry&rsquos wedding but not Charles'?                 Royal wedding: Meghan Markle&rsquos request for a &rsquoprivate&rsquo wedding REFUSEDREXMeghan talking to PR specialist Violet von Westenholtz at Wimbledon 2016Meghan was in attendance to support her close friend Serena Williams take on Russian tennis player Svetlana Kuznetsova, while Pippa was there to watch friend and Swiss champion Roger Federer.The Suits star had recently returned from a hen party in Greece, and was invited to attend Wimbledon in her role as an ambassador for Ralph Lauren.She was spotted talking to fashion PR specialist Violet von Westenholtz and stylist Olivia Buckingham in the VIP lounge, where Cressida was photographed.Ms Von Westenholtz is rumoured to be the inidual who initially set up Prince Harry and Meghan on their blind date in July 2016.Both however refused to reveal the identity of the female friend in their first joint TV interview following their engagement.Commenting on their first meeting, Meghan said she &ldquodidn&rsquot know much about Prince Harry before they met.She said: The only thing I had asked her when she said she wanted to set us up, was 'is he nice?'&ldquoIf he wasn't kind, it didn't seem like it would make sense.Prince Harry and Meghan Markle: Everything we know about the royal wedding so far -                          AFPGetty Images1 of 22Prince Harry and Meghan Markle wedding: What we know so farPrince Harry also admitted he had never watched her hit TV show Suits, but said that they fell in love &ldquoso incredibly quickly.Also in attendance at the match was American Vogue Editor Anna Wintour, who is a steadfast tennis fan and regular fixture on Wimbledon Centre Court.The Duke of Kent and Princess Michael of Kent were also spotted among the crowds on Centre Court that afternoon.Meghan and Prince Harry are set to marry on March 19 at King&rsquos George&rsquos Chapel in Windsor Castle.

title: Kate Middleton royal baby shock commentator makes bold prediction ahead of name reveal
story: Richard Fitzwilliams declared that prior to the third royal baby it was &ldquowidely rumoured the pair had been planning for a third child.However, he predicted that the latest royal baby will be the Duchess of Cambridge&rsquos last.Mr Fitzwilliams stated: &ldquoIt was widely rumoured that they wanted a third child, it will almost certainly be their last.&ldquoI&rsquom pretty certain they aren&rsquot planning for another child.GettyA royal commentator has made a bold prediction about the children of the Duchess of Cambridge                Royal baby: Baby Cambridge is likely to have THESE personality traitsThe royal expert added the latest royal baby means Prince Harry would &ldquonever be likely to become the King of England thanks to the Succession to the Crown Act.He explained: &ldquoThe Succession to the Crown Act which came into force in 2015 abolishes primogeniture, when male child took precedence.&ldquoPrince Andrew for example took precedence over Princess Anne.&ldquoPrince Harry would never be likely to become king nor would he wish to be but he is now sixth in line of succession and obviously won&rsquot.Discover where some of the potential names for the new royal baby boy could have come from.                    PA1 of 9The new royal baby boyThe latest royal baby could be named Prince Albert after a huge clue emerged.Kensington Palace appeared to create a webpage on the Royal Family website for &ldquoPrince Albert.When searching the URL https:www.royal.ukprince-albert, users are met with a page which says &ldquoACCESS DENIED - You are not authorised to access this page.This is the same page users will find who add George or Charlotte to the web link.However when searching for other popular options, such as Arthur and Alfred, users are greeted with a page instead saying &ldquoPAGE NOT FOUND - the requested page could not be found.The revelation could be a shocking clue about the royal baby&rsquos name.GettyThe latest royal baby could be named Prince Albert after a huge clue emergedGettyThe couple&rsquos final choice of name has yet to be revealedAlbert is currently the bookmakers&rsquo favourite for the Duchess of Cambridge and Prince William&rsquos third child.Despite the latest hint, the couple&rsquos final choice of name has yet to be revealed.Arthur is the favourite with Express readers - in a poll with over 64,000 participants it has emerged with 21 per cent of the vote at the time of writing.

title: Brexit news update UK citizens in Europe Dutch Government EU withdrawal deal
story: Speaking to the Dutch Parliament on Wednesday, Sarah Parkes claimed the current Brexit withdrawal agreement would not suffice to protect the rights of UK&nbspcitizens living in the EU.&nbspMs Parkes claimed that the UK Government's proposal to grant settled status to EU citizens in the UK post-Brexit would simply not work the other way around unless the EU27 agreed to provide dual citizenship rights to Britons living abroad.She said: &ldquoWith the current withdrawal agreement a reciprocation of UK proposal of settled status would not work for us.&ldquoThose of us resident in the Netherlands have many concerns and worries.&ldquoThese are just two of them. Many of us have worthy applied for and been granted permanent residency in The Netherlands as EU citizens, but what will happen when we are no longer EU citizens?                De La Rue lost to GERMAN firm as well as French contract winners&ldquoMr Rutte said that the Dutch nationals residents in the UK who wanted to become UK citizens would no longer have to give up their dual nationality.&ldquoWould the Dutch Government please also grant dual nationality to UK citizens who are long-term residents of The Netherlands but might not be married to a Dutch citizen themselves?&ldquoWe were dismayed by the result of the UK referendum about EU membership.&ldquoIndeed, quite a lot of us were denied the right to vote on this issue that has such a profound impact on our lives.&ldquoMany of those who qualify have taken dual British-Dutch citizenship.DUTCH PARLIAMENT&bullBrexit news: British expat urges Dutch Government to grant dual nationality to UK citizens &ldquoHowever, most of us do not qualify for dual citizenship and are worried about takin Dutch citizenship solely for fear of losing UK rights such as UK state or private pension, post-orce rights over our own children resident in the UK.&ldquoMost of us currently work but some on fixed-term contracts.&ldquoSadly some of us have become unemployed and having to exist on Dutch state benefits on one form or another.&ldquoAll of us are worried about our future rights as non-EU citizens to live, work and claim benefits in times of need in The Netherlands.&ldquoWe are all productive members of the Dutch society, by our work, volunteering or simply by giving a helping hand to our neighbours.&ldquoSome of us no longer have close friends or relatives in Britain because they have either died or moved outside the UK themselves.&ldquoPost-Brexit, if the Dutch state asks us to leave The Netherlands we shall have nobody to turn to and nowhere to go.Last October, Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte promised Dutch citizens living in the UK would be allowed&nbspto take up dual citizenship, according to a coalition agreement which pledged to prioritise both its people and EU unity in the&nbspBrexit&nbspnegotiations.The document read: &ldquoThe cabinet will prepare proposals for the modernisation of nationality law. It concerns an extension of the possibility of possession of multiple nationalities for prospective first-generation emigrants and immigrants.Prior to the coalition agreement, Dutch nationals who took British citizenship to avoid having to leave the UK after Brexit would have been&nbspstripped of their Netherlands passports&nbspdue to limits on dual nationality.UK citizens living in some of the EU member states face the same threat.

title: EU news France ambassador Council meeting UK English no translation
story: The European Council decided the new working group should only use English and would offer no translations when they discuss the EU&rsquos longterm budgetary future, much to the disgust of Philippe Leglise-Costa.According to several sources familiar with the meeting, the French ambassador disagreed with the move to sign off on Council representatives on using English for group&rsquos meetings on the EU&rsquos Multiannual Financial Framework.Despite the Council offering multiple translations for its high-level meetings, the French ambassador was said to have taken dissatisfaction from a decision to sign off the working group with English being its lead language.Mr Leglise-Costa was said to be defending &ldquomultilingualism as well as Francophony in a move described as a &ldquopolitical issue when he stormed out of the Coreper meeting on Wednesday.EU news: France's EU ambassador marched out of a meeting of a language disagreementOne source said the envoy made an abrupt exit from the meeting after questioning why the working group could developed into a more formal arrangement, featuring translations for other languages.A second said the issue of language had actually been resolved prior to the meeting but the &ldquoFrench raised this as an issue but more of a political issue.&ldquoThe French didn&rsquot understand the decision was already made prior to yesterday&rsquos meeting, they added.Another diplomat in the room told Politico: &ldquoFrance demanded that those who wish to speak in their language be provided interpretation.                Brexiteer businessman explodes at EU 'GENIE' trapping UK 'free spirit'                'This is fantasy!' EU diplomats pour scorn on Davis Brexit timetable&ldquoThere was a bit of tension on that Council operation.He said the issue was well handled with the decision passing &ldquoquickly and efficiently.A spokeswoman for French representation said she would not be commenting on the French ambassador&rsquos action, but it was not disputed he was unpleased with the lack of interpretations agreed for the meetings.French is one of the European Council&rsquos working languages but is often shelved for English, especially with its popularity with new members joining the EU from Eastern Europe and the Baltic.English continues as one of the EU institutions working languages, despite Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker declaring &ldquoEnglish is losing its importance in Europe.The Commission&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier has also previously snubbed the English language by delivering key Brexit announcements in French during numerous press events.

title: rail franchising system broken commuters paying price
story: Thameslink have been accused of delivering an 'appalling' service to customersThe Public Accounts Committee said: &ldquoWe are deeply concerned that the Department for Transport&rsquos management of two of its most important franchises has been completely inadequate and could be indicative of wider weaknesses in its contract management capability.But the Department for Transport dismissed the report as &ldquounbalanced and accused MPs of failing to challenge the views of the RMT rail union.The PAC said passengers on GTR&rsquos Thameslink, Southern and Great Northern franchise have suffered a &ldquodismal service since it started in 2014, with fewer than two-thirds of trains on time at one point.It accused the Government of &ldquoturning a blind eye to the risk of industrial action on these routes by letting GTR press ahead with Driver Only Operation. France travel news: SNCF and Air France staff strike TODAYThis system, which lets the driver open and shut the doors from his cab and downgrades the role of guards, has led to two years of strikes on Southern, with the dispute spreading to franchises across the country.The committee said the DfT had expected the DOO plan to cause disruption for passengers - but did not bother discussing the plans with the rail unions.The PAC was also highly critical of the running of the ECML where franchises have already failed in 2006 and 2009.Earlier this year Transport Secretary Chris Grayling told MPs that the franchise holder, Virgin Trains East Coast, would only be able to continue in its current form for a &ldquovery small number of months.Driver Only Operation has led to two years of strikesThe PAC said the DfT &ldquohas failed to learn the lessons from previous failures of the franchise, and has again allowed the operator to promise more than it could deliver.It added: &ldquoThe issues we have found with the East Coast and TSGN, and the small pool of potential bidders in the market, highlight the broken model of franchising.PAC chairman, Labour MP Meg Hillier, said: &ldquoThe operation of the Thameslink, Southern and Great Northern franchise has been a multi-faceted shambles causing untold misery for passengers.&ldquoMeanwhile, the East Coast franchise has failed for a third time because of wildly inaccurate passenger growth forecasts.&ldquoIn both cases the Government appears to have seen its task as simply to contract out the service, with wholly inadequate consideration given to passengers&rsquo best interests and behaviour.&ldquoThis imbalance cannot continue. title: scotland empty nest couples parents housing spare bedrooms retirement older people
story: SALTIRE EDINBURGHEmpty nesters are happier than ever and less likely to downsizeNew research from the Bank of Scotland reveals &ldquoa generational shift as the majority of empty nesters enjoy making the most of the new chapter in their lives.Some 60 per cent in Scotland admitted that they are enjoying the new-found space and joyfully rediscovering their independence.Half (49 per cent) said that they are now better off financially, with one in three (31 per cent) empty nesters saying they are able to travel more.Almost one in 10 (8 per cent) revealed they have had the chance to pursue a lifelong dream since their children flew the nest, while 36 per cent say they have more quality time with their grandchildren.                Nazi salute-row bigot gets &pound100,000 for appeal                Ally MacLeod wanted Scotland to fly the UNION Flag at the World Cup - STOCKMany empty nesters are using the time to explore and enjoying the new-found freedomDespite having more space around the home, almost half in Scotland say they have no plans to downsize.According to the study of more than 1,000 empty nesters, 43 per cent don&rsquot want to leave their family home because of strong links to their local area and 25 per cent want the extra space for grandchildren.Over a third (38 per cent) say that they are &ldquofinancially comfortable so have no pressing reason to downsize, while one in three (34 per cent) say moving would be a hassle.Scots are also more reluctant to leave a home full of memories (24 per cent) compared with the rest of the UK (20 per cent).Only a quarter (25 per cent) of empty nesters admitted they don&rsquot enjoy the newfound freedom, with 16 per cent saying the property feels empty.For downsizers, the main reason was to cut bills or move to a more manageable flat or bungalow. While 16 per cent say that they can no longer afford to live in a bigger home, the majority (70 per cent) expect to make money from downsizing and invest the capital. Going from a detached three bedroom home to a smaller home can typically produce a windfall of &pound67,000.Graham Blair, Bank of Scotland mortgage director, said: &ldquoIt&rsquos great to see so many of our empty nesters embracing this change, and making the most of their newfound freedom.&ldquoThis shows a generational shift, as this was often perceived to be an upsetting time for parents.&ldquoIt is also encouraging to see a significant number of homeowners looking to downsize and invest for their future movement at this end of the ladder is crucial to keep the housing market healthy.The research found that empty nesters typically have two spare bedrooms as a result of children moving out. These are usually kept as spare bedrooms (63 per cent) or home offices (30 per cent). More than one in 10 (13 per cent) convert a bedroom into a hobby room. But almost a fifth (18 per cent) said that their kids&rsquo bedrooms stayed unchanged after they moved out.

title: Hungary Gergely Guly s Viktor Orban slams EU meddling domestic migration policy
story: Referring to the growing migration crisis in Europe, the politician said: &ldquoMigration will be one of the most important issues here in the next decades, in Europe and all around the world, therefore we must have a policy about migration.&ldquoWe respect the opinions of other countries, because they belong to member states of the European Union.He however shot back at criticism from other EU nations, stating: &ldquoBut we expect that the other countries will respect our democratic decisions.This comes after Hungary&rsquos far-right Prime Minister Viktor Orban was re-elected earlier this month with a landslide victory, after fighting his campaign on a fiercely anti-immigration platform. to become intimidated.&ldquoWe are described as an agent of George Soros, we are said to be complicit in global conspiracy where the European institutions in Brussels, Soros, civil society, activists and groups are wanting to drive millions of migrants, Muslim migrants to Europe and Hungary with the aim of destroying our cultural and religious legacy and identity.Migrants protest outside Budapest's Keleti Railway Station after it was closed off by police to prevent people travelling on to western Europe                    REUTERS1 of 53A migrant taunts Hungarian riot police as they fire tear gas and water cannon on the Serbian side of the border, near RoszkeProfessor Zoltan Fleck from the Eotvos Lorand University in Budapest also noted that these worrying progressions can be found in the field of law.Questioned whether the Hungarian judiciary is now largely controlled by a Fidesz party loyalist, he said: &ldquoYes, it is very dangerous, because all the relevant issues about the administration of the judiciary such as the appointment of judges, selecting the leaders of the judiciary, and the remuneration of the judges is defined by this head of the office.And sending a warning message about the future of Europe, Professor Michael Ignatieff said: &ldquoMy issue with Viktor Orban is not whether or not he has a mandate, but what democracy is?&ldquoThe question will have to be asked, if you have a European member state that doesn&rsquot subscribe to core European values, what do you do?&ldquoNobody knows whether Europe will cross that bridge, but if it doesn&rsquot ask those questions, Europe may not survive.

story: The Heineken-brewed bottle label features a map of South America including Argentina and the off-shore Falkland Islands - known as Las Islas Malvinas in the Spanish-speaking state.The bottle was designed for drinkers in France but used yeast sourced in Argentina and the commemorative label was intended to reflect this.The French label identified the islands, which are located 7,000 miles from the UK, as &lsquo&Icircles Falkland&rsquo.The landmass was accompanied by &lsquo(UK)&rsquo - a move which has drawn ire in Argentina, who still claim the territory as their own.A photo of the H41 beer bottle was shared online by a furious Argentine, who said the manufacturers were &ldquoidiots.TWITTER  Falkland Islands ROW: Argentina has blown its cool over a beer bottleTWITTER  CASANOVEROThe offending beer bottle identified the Falkland Islands as belonging to the UKHe tweeted: &ldquoHello Heineken, I have a little problem with H41. I am going to show you.You wrote the Malvinas belong to the UK. You use Patagonian yeast and you go and do that, you idiots!Heineken&rsquos Argentina branch quickly issued an apology and promised the label would be altered.They said: This limited edition product was not being sold in South America and when the Heineken Argentina team became aware it requested the change at the global level.&ldquoAll the labels involved in this edition in the world will be changed.The Falklands War, also known as the Falklands Conflict, Falklands Crisis, and the Guerra del Atl&aacutentico Sur, was a ten-week war between Argentina and the United Kingdom, 2 April  &ndash 14 June 1982.                     Getty Images1 of 24Surgeon Lt Gordon Brooks with wife Christine and 3-month-old daughter Helen. Britain went to war with Argentina over the Falkland Islands in 1982. title: Alfie Evans update people gather in Vatican to pray for 23 month old health latest
story: GettyA Novena vigil prayer dedicated to Alfie Evans has taken placePictures show people crowed in St Peter's square in the Vatican with lit candles as part of the emotional gesture.On Thursday The Catholic Association called on British authorities to allow the terminally ill toddler to travel to Italy for treatment.The policy advisor for The Catholic Association (TCA), Dr Grazie Pozo Christie, stated he did not understand why hospitals across Britain have not rallied behind a transfer to Italy for medical care.Mr Pozo Christie stated: &ldquoThe plight of Alfie Evans and his young parents has horrified people across the world who are watching as a powerful state withholds water and oxygen from a sick toddler, against the wishes of his desperate mother and father.                Alfie Evans: 'Alfie's Law' campaign for end-of-life care launched&ldquoBambino Gesu Hospital in Rome, at the behest of Pope Francis, is ready and willing to care for the child &ndash not promising a cure, which may not exist, but respecting their parental judgment and offering to accompany both Alfie and his family through this tragic situation.&ldquoWhy UK hospital authorities are standing in the way is beyond comprehension.Earlier this week the High Court ruled that Alfie, suffering from a degenerative neurological disorder, should not leave the country out of his &ldquobest interests.Yesterday Alfie&rsquos father, Tom Evans, called off &ldquoAlfie&rsquos Army and praised NHS staff that had been caring for his son.Alfie has a degenerative neurological condition which has not been definitively diagnosed after being born in a semi-vegetative state.                    Facebook1 of 16Tom Evans has launched legal action against three doctors treating his sonMr Evans promised to &ldquowork with doctors and &ldquoform a relationship going forward.He explained: &ldquoOur lives have been turned upside down by the intense focus on Alfie and his situation.&ldquoWe would now ask you to return back to your everyday lives and allow myself, Kate and Alder Hey to form a relationship, build a bridge and walk across it.&ldquoWe also wish to thank Alder Hey staff at every level for their dignity and professionalism during what must be an incredibly difficult time for them too.&ldquoIn Alfie&rsquos interests we will work with his treating team on a plan that provides our boy with the dignity and comfort he needs.From this point onwards, there will be no more statements issued or interviews given. We hope you will respect this.The father iterated that Alfie &ldquodoesn&rsquot need intensive care anymore as he pleaded for the 23-month-old to be taken home.GettyPictures show people crowed in St Peter's square in the VaticanGettyTom Evans called off 'Alfie&rsquos Army' and praised NHS staff that had been caring for his sonHe went on: &ldquoAlfie doesn&rsquot need intensive care anymore. Alfie is lying on the bed with one litre of oxygen going into his lungs and the rest is him.&ldquoHe hasn&rsquot woken up, he&rsquos still a little bit weak, but what we ask for is to go home to sustain his life.&ldquoAs I sit next to Alfie&rsquos bedside, every second of every day, it encourages me more and more that he will live for &lsquox&rsquo amount of months, possibly years.

title: North Korea inter Korea summit Kim Jong un departs Pyongyang denuclearisation
story: Kim Jong-un and Moon Jae-in will meet to discuss issues of peace and denuclearisationNorth Korean state news agency KCNA reported the two leaders will &ldquoopen-heartedly discuss issues of peace, prosperity and reunification.They said: Kim Jong-un will open-heartedly discuss with Moon Jae-in all the issues arising in improving inter-Korean relations and achieving peace, prosperity and reunification of the Korean peninsula.The two leaders will meet at Peace House in the border truce village of Panmunjom on the southern side of the demilitarised zone that stands between the two countries.South Korea&rsquos Moon will greet Kim at the military demarcation line at 9.30am (00.30 GMT), and the two will be escorted by South Korean honour guards to an official welcoming ceremony before beginning official dialogue at 10.30am.Kim will become the first North Korean leader to set foot in South Korea since the 1950-53 Korean War.                North Korea &lsquoready to sell more chemical weapons after Syria attack'                White House reveals Kim Jong-un summit with PompeoSouth Korea hopes Kim will confirm his will for 'complete' denuclearisationThree key issues will be on the agenda when the two leaders sit down together improvement of inter-Korea relations after decades-long rivalry, a peace settlement, and denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula.South Korea hopes Kim will directly confirm his will for complete denuclearisation of the peninsula.The two countries are also expected to release a joint statement late on Friday, possibly called the Panmunjom Declaration, that could address issues surrounding the improvement of relations and peace.KCNA news agency also stated Kim would plant a memorial tree with Moon at the meeting as a symbol of growing peace between the nations.Analysts and commentators however remain sceptical about whether the dictator will really abandon North Korea&rsquos nuclear arsenal which he has developed for decades to defend against apparent U.S. invasions and aggressions.Duyeon Kim, visiting senior fellow at the Korean Peninsula Future Forum, said: The problem has always been the two Koreas have never been able to fully implement their past agreements that agree on peace and establishing peace.In practical terms, what's the first step you take toward peace?Evans Revere, former State Department expert on North Korea, also said: &ldquoOne of the critical priorities for the South Korean President I think is to try to get them on the record saying something more substantial and concrete in terms of denuclearisation.Photographer Eric Lafforgue ventured to North Korea six times. Thanks to digital memory cards, he was able to save photos that was forbidden to take inside the segregated state                     Eric LafforgueExclusivepix Medi1 of 69Taking pictures in the DMZ is easy, but if you come too close to the soldiers, they stop youThe North Korean language thus far has not been very specific.&ldquoThat suggests that they're not being particularly serious about denuclearisation.The summit sets the stage for Kim to meet with US President Donald Trump in late May or early June, in what will be the first meeting between the leaders of the two countries.Trump recently exchanged threats with the North Korean leader and referred to him as &ldquolittle rocket man, which raised fears of fresh conflict on the Korean peninsula.
